awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Collaborative Research: Synchronization Between Terrestrial and Aquatic Ecosystems
awd_abstract_narration:
Aquatic ecosystems are closely connected to their surrounding watersheds through the flux of water, nutrients, and organic carbon.  Similarly, the flux of exogenous carbon from the landscape causes lakes to be substantial sources of greenhouse gases as well as sinks for organic carbon buried in the sediment.  There are also important fluxes from inland waters to the terrestrial ecosystems. Despite the recognition of the importance of terrestrial-aquatic coupling, synchronization (persistent relatedness) of dynamics between these ecosystems has not been broadly investigated.  Employing data reuse techniques to use data from Lake Multiscaled Geospatial and Temporal Database (LAGOS) and Global Lake Ecological Observatory Network (GLEON) databases, the PIs will apply new analysis tools to answer questions related to the synchrony of lakes and their surrounding watersheds.
 
To quantify synchronization between terrestrial and aquatic habitats wavelet coherence will be used to measure the strength of synchronization between terrestrial and lake ecosystems, as well as phase relationships, describing time lags. Time lags are hypothesized to reflect mechanisms of synchrony and may be related to lake size, water residence time, trophic status, and watershed area. These factors are hypothesized to affect the degree of aquatic-terrestrial synchrony. Random forest regression will be applied to test this idea, leveraging the range of lake and watershed properties. Multiple regression for wavelet transforms will be used to determine the fraction of aquatic-terrestrial synchrony that can be explained by climate drivers and assess synchrony between terrestrial ecosystems and lake nutrient fluctuations for improved inference into non-climate mechanisms of synchrony.
 
This project is supported by the National Science Foundation?s Public Access Initiative which is managed by the NSF Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure on behalf of the Foundation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Our project reused existing data to explore new questions about the relationships between terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems with newly developed statistical techniques. Specifically, we asked if the annual patterns of ?greening? (production of new organic matter, e.g., leaves) on land is coherent with the annual patterns of ?greening? (production of algae) in aquatic systems. By coherent we mean: do the fluctuations in greenness vary together and what are the phases (i.e., time lags) of these relationships? We also asked what factors influence the strength and phase of coherence and examined possible watershed and aquatic ecosystem characteristics in this regard. The core of our analysis was based on data from satellites that continuously monitor terrestrial vegetation and the NSF-funded LAGOS (Lake multi-scaled geo-spatial and temporal database) that compiled data on lakes. For lakes we assembled data on direct measures of chlorophyll concentrations which are a measure of the biomass of algae.

As we preceded with our study two new question emerged. First, we asked what is the relationship of lake size to watershed size? This question was important for determining the scale for assessing terrestrial ecosystems relative to aquatic ecosystems. Second, by assembling data on algal biomass from hundreds of lakes we were able to ask whether algal blooms (i.e., overgrowths of algae) were becoming more common.

Our project had the following major outcomes.

1)    In an essay we expressed a rationale for investigating and understanding multi-annual dynamics of ecosystems. Inter-annual variability is a pervasive feature of ecosystems. This variability results from short-term and long-term dynamics caused by environmental processes like climate variability and land use change. While short-term variability and forecasting directional change are important research issues, relatively little attention has been given to the interaction of oscillatory, or wave-like dynamics, across longer time scales. This work made the case for evaluating dynamics beyond ?trends? and toward assessing multi-annual patterns to better forecast ecological change.

2)    Using the data from the LAGOS database and satellite products, we found that annual primary production (greenness) in lakes and the surrounding landscape can exhibit strong, persistent, temporal relationships (i.e., coherence). The strength and phase of these relationship is quite variable among lakes. Hydrologic connectivity (inputs, outputs, and flow paths of water) and intermediary wetlands explained much of the variability in coherence. Surprisingly, we did not find that climatic variability played a large role.

3)    We collected data from a variety of studies to determine lake-watershed size relationships. There is a strong relationship between lake size and watershed size and different data sets produce a common slope (i.e., same rate of increase of size).

4)    Algal blooms, the rapid proliferation of algal biomass often to nuisance or harmful levels, diminish aquatic ecosystem services (e.g., swimmable waters). The interaction between nutrient over-enrichment of water bodies and climate change has been hypothesized to drive widespread intensification of algal blooms in inland waters. We investigated trends in the occurrence and magnitudes of blooms in 323 lakes. We found that algal bloom intensification in inland waterbodies for a large region of the United States has not been widespread. Only one in ten lakes had significant bloom intensification whereas one in six waterbodies had significantly improved with regards to annual bloom occurrence during the same period.

5)    Students increasingly need to use, manipulate, and understand complex data. We developed and tested a teaching module aimed at upper-level environmental science students that built on the themes of the research activities funded by this grant. The purpose of the activity was for students to practice plotting time series of data, creating professional quality graphs for further data analysis, and evaluate the time series for trends and wavy patterns. Pre- and post-assessment of the students documented improved understanding of oscillatory trends in temporal data as well as better ability to propose hypotheses about reasons for the observed patterns.

Overall, our project demonstrated the value and benefits of reusing existing long-term environmental data to test new questions. We documented multi-annual patterns in the dynamics of terrestrial and aquatic ecosystem and established connections between these systems related to hydrology and wetland proximity. We determined for a large population of lakes that algal blooms are not increasing for a large area of the United States. This finding is contrary to impressions given in popular media as well as a few scientific studies that investigated a smaller number of lakes.
